class Codes.forms.DocumentForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ModelForm

This form is used to upload file(s) as Document instances. It uses Django’s ModelForm functionality to generate a field based on the Document model’s ‘file’ field. It uses a custom widget to allow multiple file uploads.

Parameters:

forms.ModelForm (class) – Inherits from Django’s ModelForm class.

Codes.models module

class Codes.models.Code(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

The Code class represents a code snippet entity within a project.

Parameters:

models.Model – Django’s base model class from which Code inherits.

Variables:

  • id (models.UUIDField) – Unique identifier for the code snippet.

  • owner (models.ForeignKey) – Reference to the User who owns the code snippet.

  • project (models.ForeignKey) – Reference to the Project the code snippet is part of.

  • title (models.CharField) – The code snippet’s title.

  • description (models.CharField) – A short description of the code snippet.

  • source_code (models.TextField) – The code snippet’s content.

  • code_tag (models.ForeignKey) – The tag associated with the code snippet.

  • plagiarism_ratio (models.PositiveIntegerField) – The plagiarism ratio of the code snippet.

  • plagiarized_from (models.ForeignKey) – The reference to the original code snippet from which this code was plagiarized.

  • creation_date (models.DateTimeField) – The date and time the code snippet was created.

  • last_edit (models.DateTimeField) – The date and time the code snippet was last edited.

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

_meta = <Options for Code>
code_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

code_tag

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

class Codes.models.Document(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Represents a document entity that can be associated with a code snippet.

Args:

models (Model): Django’s base model class from which Document inherits.

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

_meta = <Options for Document>
file

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)
id

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>
class Codes.models.Project(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

The Project class represents a project entity.

Parameters:

models.Model – Django’s base model class from which Project inherits.

Variables:

  • id (models.UUIDField) – Unique identifier for the project.

  • owner (models.ForeignKey) – Reference to the User who owns the project.

  • title (models.CharField) – The project’s title.

  • description (models.CharField) – A short description of the project.

  • creation_date (models.DateTimeField) – The date and time the project was created.

  • last_edit (models.DateTimeField) – The date and time the project was last edited.

Codes.signals module

Codes.signals.delete_favorite_project(sender, instance, **kwargs)[source]

This function is triggered after a project instance is deleted. If the deleted project was set as favorite, it attempts to set another project as favorite.

Parameters:

  • sender (django.db.models.Model) – The model class.

  • instance (models.Model) – The actual instance being deleted.

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments

Codes.signals.select_favorite_project(sender, instance, created, **kwargs)[source]

This function is triggered after a project instance is saved. It checks if the project’s owner has a favorite project, if not, it sets the current project as favorite.

Parameters:

  • sender (django.db.models.Model) – The model class.

  • instance (models.Model) – The actual instance being saved.

  • created (bool) – A boolean; True if a new record was created.

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments

Codes.signals.start_plagiarism_checks(sender, instance, **kwargs)[source]

This function is triggered before a code snippet instance is saved. It checks if there are any changes in the source code and if so, it queues it for plagiarism check.

Parameters:

  • sender (django.db.models.Model) – The model class.

  • instance (models.Model) – The actual instance being saved.

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments

Codes.signals.update_code_tag(sender, instance, created, **kwargs)[source]

This function is triggered after a code snippet instance is saved. It updates the code tag of the snippet based on its file extension.

Parameters:

  • sender (django.db.models.Model) – The model class.

  • instance (models.Model) – The actual instance being saved.

  • created (bool) – A boolean; True if a new record was created.

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments

Codes.tests module

Codes.urls module

Codes.views module

Codes.views.addProject(request)[source]

This view is used to handle the creation of new projects. It takes a POST request with the new project’s information, validates it, and if everything checks out, creates a new project and redirects the user to their account page.

Parameters:

request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.add_code(request, project_id)[source]

This view is used to add a code to a project. The user must be the owner of the project to add code to it. If the user is not the owner, they are redirected to their account page with an error message.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • project_id (int) – The ID of the project to which code will be added.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.deleteProject(request, project_id)[source]

This view is used to handle the deletion of an existing project. The user must be the owner of the project to delete it. If the user is not the owner, they are redirected to their account page with an error message.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • project_id (int) – The ID of the project to be deleted.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.delete_code(request, code_id)[source]

This view is used to handle the deletion of an existing code. The user must be the owner of the code to delete it. If the user is not the owner, they are redirected to their account page with an error message.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • code_id (int) – The ID of the code to be deleted.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.displayMyProject(request, project_id)[source]

This view is used to display a specific project’s details. It only shows the projects that are owned by the current user. If the project is not found or the user is not the owner, a 404 error is raised.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • project_id (int) – The ID of the project to be displayed.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.editProject(request, project_id)[source]

This view is used to handle the editing of an existing project. The user must be the owner of the project to edit it. If the user is not the owner, they are redirected to their account page with an error message.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • project_id (int) – The ID of the project to be edited.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse

Codes.views.edit_code(request, code_id)[source]

This view is used to handle the editing of an existing code. The user must be the owner of the code to edit it. If the user is not the owner, they are redirected to their account page with an error message.

Parameters:

  • request (django.core.handlers.wsgi.WSGIRequest) – The HTTP request.

  • code_id (int) – The ID of the code to be edited.

Returns:

The HTTP response.

Return type:

django.http.HttpResponse
